entry.title: @HughEverett on 2025-03-20 00:02:23+00:00 (#9218)

entry.title: @HughEverett on 2025-03-20 00:00:50+00:00 (#9211)
entry.content: You can't do it, Intel won't allow it. That's why HyperDbg automatically configures the (read to FALSE) bit.

entry.title: @HughEverett on 2025-03-19 23:59:34+00:00 (#9210)
entry.content: HyperDbg allows all of the possible combination. The only thing that is not allowed is a page that you want to intercept its reads but not writes. (It automatically sets the write to FALSE) because it's not supported in Intel processors (you'll get a VM error if you configure it like this).

entry.title: @honorary_bot on 2025-03-19 23:59:31+00:00 (#9209)
entry.content: Ohh, but that's a manual page walk with an actual pte access

entry.title: @honorary_bot on 2025-03-19 22:52:19+00:00 (#9181)
entry.content: Monitoring all page table accesses doesn't make sense

entry.title: @honorary_bot on 2025-03-19 22:51:50+00:00 (#9180)
entry.content: Also, if you need to monitor page table changes, why don't you trap just writes?

entry.title: @honorary_bot on 2025-03-19 22:47:32+00:00 (#9179)
entry.content: Obviously instruction fetch also causes ept violation btw, so every instruction would cause a EPT violation

entry.content: wait i will make some screen and show you

entry.content: but what i dont understand now

entry.content: got your point bro it seems logic

entry.title: @honorary_bot on 2025-03-19 22:36:43+00:00 (#9169)
entry.content: so consulted with the cache entry anyway

entry.title: @honorary_bot on 2025-03-19 22:36:30+00:00 (#9168)
entry.content: in fact if it's not in the cache, it is fetched into the cache first

entry.title: @honorary_bot on 2025-03-19 22:36:09+00:00 (#9167)
entry.content: yeah, no matter if it's cached or fetched from the memory

entry.title: @6176993302 on 2025-03-19 22:35:47+00:00 (#9166)
entry.content: in other words the ept violation will happen for sure right

entry.title: @honorary_bot on 2025-03-19 22:31:06+00:00 (#9165)
entry.content: Oh, I got it, tlb cache entries actually hold ept rwxu bits, so even if they are cached in tlb, they are still consulted for a possible ept violation exit

entry.title: @6176993302 on 2025-03-19 22:29:53+00:00 (#9164)
entry.content: and when i applied the monitor rw hook on the PML4E it generate an infinite loop of MFT exit events

entry.title: @6176993302 on 2025-03-19 22:29:24+00:00 (#9163)
entry.content: at the start of EptHookHandleMonitorTrapFlag

entry.title: @6176993302 on 2025-03-19 22:29:12+00:00 (#9162)
entry.content: i have modified the code of the MFT handler by adding a debug message : LogInfo("Inside the MonitorTrapFlag handler again ");

entry.title: @honorary_bot on 2025-03-19 22:28:52+00:00 (#9161)
entry.content: Well, too bad :)

entry.title: @6176993302 on 2025-03-19 22:27:41+00:00 (#9159)
entry.content: thats a strange world

entry.title: @6176993302 on 2025-03-19 22:27:37+00:00 (#9158)
entry.content: well each time we discover some strange behavior in virtualization xd

entry.title: @honorary_bot on 2025-03-19 21:41:20+00:00 (#9157)
entry.content: But that's interesting, never thought of this use case

entry.title: @honorary_bot on 2025-03-19 21:40:37+00:00 (#9156)
entry.content: Do you actually get VM-exits logged on PML4 lookups? Because those are supposed to be cached in TLB all the time

entry.title: @honorary_bot on 2025-03-19 21:39:17+00:00 (#9155)
entry.content: Got it, EPT violation due to dirty bits update?

entry.title: @6176993302 on 2025-03-19 21:31:45+00:00 (#9154)
entry.content: mmmmmmm my assumption was that probably the PML4 table is heavily accessed since thats the start point of translating addresses and when you try to put any monitor point on some specific PML4E it will end up triggering any read/write in the table since its seize is exactly 0x1000 bytes

entry.title: @honorary_bot on 2025-03-19 21:06:21+00:00 (#9153)
entry.content: Dirty bit don't cause VM-exits

entry.title: @honorary_bot on 2025-03-19 21:05:54+00:00 (#9152)
entry.content: Can you elaborate more on this dirty bit problem? I didn't catch the exact problem

entry.title: @HughEverett on 2025-03-19 20:52:46+00:00 (#9151)
entry.content: The 'dirty' bit is an example, there might be other bits as well.

entry.title: @HughEverett on 2025-03-19 20:52:13+00:00 (#9150)
entry.content: I encountered this problem a few years ago. The problem is not because of the HyperDbg's implementation. My conclusion was that there are some bits (like dirty bit in the page table) that cause a VM-exit once they're applied by CPU. But, we couldn't re-apply them to the memory as they don't have an instruction for applying the dirty bit and it's the processor that applies it. I think the reason why HyperDbg hangs is because of this (but I'm not sure and I couldn't verify the assumption).

entry.title: @6176993302 on 2025-03-18 21:51:43+00:00 (#9149)
entry.content: hyperdbg 0.13

entry.title: @6176993302 on 2025-03-18 21:50:11+00:00 (#9148)
entry.content: to be more specific the system freez "sometimes" and sometimes it continue working
